title: Iran Nuclear Strikes Deliver Strategic Benefits to Saudi Business Partners
summary: Trump ordered Operation Midnight Hammer strikes on June 21-22, 2025, hitting Iran's Fordow, Natanz, Isfahan nuclear sites with B-2 bombers carrying 14 GBU-57 30,000-lb bunker busters and submarine Tomahawks. Strikes benefited Saudi strategic interests while Trump maintained business ties. Saudi Arabia, UAE surprisingly condemned strikes as "violation of sovereignty," citing business disruption concerns. DIA assessed strikes set Iran program back "few months," not "obliterated."

notes: Gulf states previously pushed Trump for new nuclear deal, not strikes. Saudi-Iran restored diplomatic ties 2023 after China-brokered talks. 2019 Iran attack on Saudi oil facilities was "turning point" pushing Saudis toward detente. Gulf states feared strikes would disrupt oil production, block Strait of Hormuz shipping. Renad Mansour (Chatham House): "The gulf largely has a business-first mindset, and instability is bad for business." Iran threatened retaliation against US troops in Bahrain, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi, UAE.
